sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a neutralization reaction
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change for the neutralization of hydrochloric acid (HCl) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) to form sodium chloride (NaCl) and water (H2O), given the following balanced chemical equation and standard enthalpies of formation:

HCl (aq) + NaOH (aq) → NaCl (aq) + H2O (l)

ΔH°f (HCl) = -92.31 kJ/mol
ΔH°f (NaOH) = -469.14 kJ/mol
ΔH°f (NaCl) = -384.50 kJ/mol
ΔH°f (H2O) = -285.83 kJ/mol
message_2:
To find the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use Hess's Law, which states that the total enthalpy change for a reaction is the sum of the enthalpy changes for each step in the reaction. In this case, we can use the standard enthalpies of formation for the reactants and products.

ΔH°rxn = Σ ΔH°f (products) - Σ ΔH°f (reactants)

For the given reaction:

ΔH°rxn = [ΔH°f (NaCl) + ΔH°f (H2O)] - [ΔH°f (HCl) + ΔH°f (NaOH)]

ΔH°rxn = [(-384.50 kJ/mol) + (-285.83 kJ/mol)] - [(-92.31 kJ/mol) + (-469.14 kJ/mol)]

ΔH°rxn = (-670.33 kJ/mol) - (-561.45 kJ/mol)

ΔH°rxn = -108.88 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the neutralization of hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide to form sodium chloride and water is -108.88 kJ/mol.
